L'Arrivee = The Arrival
group_siblings.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio

group_siblings.title: Outer space
group_siblings.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio

results.title: L'Arrivee = The Arrival
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description:
‘L’Arrivee’ is Tscherkassky’s second homage to the Lumiere-brothers. First you see the arrival of the film itself, which shows the arrival of a train at a station. But that train collides with a second train, causing a violent crash, which leads us to an unexpected third arrival, the arrival of a beautiful woman, the happy-end.

Reduced to two minutes, ‘L’Arrivee’ gives a brief, but exact summary of what cinematography (after its arrival with Lumieres train) has made into an enduring presence of our visual environment: violence, emotions. Or, as an anonymous American housewife (cited by T. W. Adorno) used to describe Hollywood’s version of life: ‘Getting into trouble and out of it again.’
results.description:
‘L’Arrivee’ is Tscherkassky’s second homage to the Lumiere-brothers. First you see the arrival of the film itself, which shows the arrival of a train at a station. But that train collides with a second train, causing a violent crash, which leads us to an unexpected third arrival, the arrival of a beautiful woman, the happy-end.

Reduced to two minutes, ‘L’Arrivee’ gives a brief, but exact summary of what cinematography (after its arrival with Lumieres train) has made into an enduring presence of our visual environment: violence, emotions. Or, as an anonymous American housewife (cited by T. W. Adorno) used to describe Hollywood’s version of life: ‘Getting into trouble and out of it again.’

But that train collides with a second train, causing a violent crash, which leads us to an unexpected third arrival, the arrival of a beautiful woman, the happy-end.

Reduced to two minutes, ‘L’Arrivee’ gives a brief, but exact summary of what cinematography (after its arrival with Lumieres train) has made into an enduring presence of our visual environment: violence, emotions. Or, as an anonymous American housewife (cited by T. W. Adorno) used to describe Hollywood’s version of life: ‘Getting into trouble and out of it again.’

results.title: Rev
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: This painterly observation of pedestrian traffic through a revolving door finds a counterpoint in the flickering of a candle flame. As separate lives are blurred with the energy of constant movement, individuals merge into an abstracted urban sound and light space.
results.description: This painterly observation of pedestrian traffic through a revolving door finds a counterpoint in the flickering of a candle flame. As separate lives are blurred with the energy of constant movement, individuals merge into an abstracted urban sound and light space.
